newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel to privatise banks via share offerings.
newsitem.headline: Israel to privatise banks via share offerings.

text.p: M.I. Holdings, the state company in charge of privatising Israel's banks, has decided to sell bank shares through public offerings while pursuing the option of selling controlling stakes to strategic investors, a government source said.
The decision was made after attempts to sell controlling stakes in Israel's biggest banks, Hapoalim and Leumi, ran into difficulties when bidders withdrew their offers.

Edmond Safra, who controls Republic New York Corp, was the sole bidder for Leumi until he withdrew his bid. A consortium led by Israeli businessman Eliezer Fishman is the only bidder for Hapoalim after a group led by Claridge Israel -- the Israeli investment vehicle of Charles Bronfman -- dropped out in August.
The government source said public offerings for about 10 percent of the banks' shares would be made on stock markets in Tel Aviv, Europe and the United States.
The new programme is comprised of share offerings in three of Israel's five major banks -- Leumi, United Mizrahi Bank and Israel Discount Bank, the source said.
He said it had not yet been decided whether a similar offering would be done for Hapoalim.
The decision on where to hold the offerings and in what order would be made according to circumstances at the time of the offerings, the source said.
Hapoalim, Discount and Leumi already trade in Tel Aviv.
A controlling 26 percent stake in Mizrahi was sold last year to the Ofer Wertheim groups but a public offering was scrapped at the last minute due to a prolonged labour dispute.
Last March the government sold a 14.5 percent stake in Discount in shares and options on the Tel Aviv market.
The government source as well as a Treasury spokesman refused to confirm a report in the Maariv daily that the first share offering would be for Discount.
